thread.title: GPT Metro office beats forecasts with $35.7m inaugural profit
thread.title_full: GPT Metro office beats forecasts with $35.7m inaugural profit

title: GPT Metro office beats forecasts with $35.7m inaugural profit
text:
An artists impression of Samsung's Australian headquarters at 3 Murray Rose Avenue, at Olympic Park, Homebush in Sydney.
GPT Metro Office Fund has posted an inaugural profit of $35.7 million, which exceeded its forecasts made in the float 8 months ago.
The rise in demand for residential development tightened supply of suburban offices, leading to solid rent rises, which underpinned the result.
The fund upgraded its forecast earnings to 19.12¢ per unit and forecast distribution to 17.80¢ per unit for the period from allotment to December 31.
GPT Metropolitan Office Fund's Vantage property at 109 Burwood Road Hawthorn, Melbourne.
The results were also boosted by a $24 million lift in property valuations.
Advertisement In its first 8 months, the fund exceeded its product disclosure statement (PDS) expectations for the period achieving earnings per unit of 11.28¢, above the forecast of 10.33¢, and a distribution of 10.15¢ per unit, which is 3.5 per cent above PDS forecast.
The group's fund manager, Chris Blackmore, said there were cost savings, tenant retentions and higher rents over the period ending June 30.
Mr Blackmore said the fund, which was born out of the GPT Group in January, would take a "patient and disciplined" approach to asset acquisitions with a focus along the Eastern seaboard.
Property analysts said it was a market bellwether for the metropolitan sector, particularly for the growth region of western Sydney.
UBS said there were good leasing outcomes and confidence has been shown in the management to sign new leases.
"We see Melbourne and Sydney as the growth centres, with our properties standing at 95.9 per cent occupied. Samsung has increased it space at Sydney Olympic Park, while McConnell Dowell has signed for another 7 years at the Vantage, Melbourne site," Mr Blackmore said.
The focus on costs saw the gearing maintained at 28.9 per cent with a low weighted average cost of debt of 4.8 per cent. The fund has also activated its distribution reinvestment plan (DRP) for the June 2015 distribution.
"The result reflects the strong position of the fund which has a high quality portfolio of six A-Grade metropolitan and business park office properties. Over the eight months to 30 June 2015, the portfolio has experienced a $24 million uplift in asset value ," he said.
Mr Blackmore said Australian metropolitan office markets have been tracking in line with economic growth, with the strongest markets in Sydney and Melbourne.
He said that while incentives in lease contracts, such as office fit out and rent free period, accounted for about 27 per cent, there was also genuine "net face and effective" rent increases.
"Market fundamentals indicate a stable outlook for metropolitan office markets across Australia. This is having a positive flow-on impact to capital values of assets in metropolitan office markets," Mr Blackmore said.
"In the Sydney metropolitan office markets, where the fund has 54 per cent exposure, we have seen office demand and rental growth continue to strengthen, supported by an improving NSW economy.
"The Victorian economy, which was the fastest growing in Australia, was expected to support office employment growth which, when combined with low supply, indicates solid rental growth opportunities in Melbourne metropolitan office markets."
